title: Trump: $54B Defense Spending Increase Shows World America Serious About Winning
text:
Trump: $54B Defense Spending Increase Shows World America Serious About Winning "... rebuild the depleted military ..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
President Donald Trump is proposing a $54 billion increase in defense spending that will be balanced by cuts in other areas, administration officials said Monday. 
The president spoke about his plan while addressing the nation’s governors at the White House. 
“This budget will be a public safety and national security budget,” Trump said, noting it would include a “historic increase in defense spending to rebuild the depleted military.” Advertisement - story continues below Ben Stein: Media Looking To Give Trump The Nixon Treatment 
“This is a landmark event and message to the world in these dangerous times, of American strength, security and resolve. We must ensure that our courageous servicemen and women have the tools they need to deter war and when called upon to fight in our name, only do one thing: win,” he said. 
Trump said despite cuts, domestic programs will meet the needs of the people. 
“We are going to do more with less and make the government lean and accountable to the people,” the president added. “We can do so much more with the money we spend.” Advertisement - story continues below 
During a call with reporters, an official at the Office of Management and Budget filled in several details. 
“Most federal agencies will see a reduction as a result,” the official said, with cuts falling most heavily on “lower priority” programs as well as foreign aid. 
The administration “expects the rest of the world to step up in some of the programs this country has been so generous in funding in the past,” the official said when asked about slashing foreign aid. 
Funding for the Environmental Protection Agency could be cut below its current $8.3 billion. Myron Ebell, who led the EPA transition team for Trump, told Bloomberg 15,000 EPA jobs could be cut nationwide. Advertisement - story continues below
